msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.l: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

‘Sanctify
to me all the firstborn, the opening of the womb among the children
of Israel, both of man and of animal: it is mine.’

And Moses said to the people, ‘Remember this day,
in which you came out from Egypt, from the reign of slaves, because
the Lord brought you out from this place by a strong hand. And no leavened |bread| shall be eaten.
Today you are going out, in the month of Baš Qusqan.

And it shall be, when the Lord brings you to the land of the Canaanites,
and the Hittites, and the Amorites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites,
which he swore to your fathers to give you, a land flowing |with| milk
and honey, that you shall keep this service in this
month.

Seven days you shall eat unleavened bread, and
on the seventh day: a feast to the Lord.

Seven days shall unleavened bread
be eaten, and there shall be no leavened |bread| seen with you, and
there shall be no leaven seen with you in all your borders.

And
you shall tell your son in that day, saying, “Because of that |which|
the Lord did to me when I went out from Egypt.”

And it shall
be for a sign to you on your hand, and for a memorial between your eyes, that
the Lord’s Law may be in your mouth, because with a strong hand
has the Lord brought you out from Egypt.

And you shall keep
this statute at its appointed time from year to year.

And
it shall be, when the Lord shall bring you to the land of the Canaanites, as
he swore to you and to your fathers, and he would give it to you,

that you shall pass all the openings of the womb to the Lord; and every opening
|of the womb| of the progeny of livestock which you have, the males, are the Lord’s.

And you shall redeem every opening of the womb of a donkey
with a sheep, and if you do not redeem it, then you shall stab it to death, and
you shall redeem all the firstborn of man among your children.

And it shall be, when
your son asks you some time, saying, “What is this?”, you shall say to him,
“The Lord brought us out from Egypt, from the reign of slaves by a strong hand.

And it was, when Pharaoh hardened his heart and
kept refusing to let us go, that the Lord slew all the firstborn in the land
of Egypt, from the firstborn of man, to the firstborn of animal.
On account of this I sacrifice to the Lord all openings of the womb,
the males, and I redeem all the firstborn of my children.”

And it shall be for a sign on your hand, and for frontlets
between your eyes, because with strength of hand the Lord brought us out
from Egypt.’
Parashat Beshalach

And it was, when Pharaoh had let
the people go, that God led them not
by way of the land of the Philistines, although that was near, because God said,
‘Lest the people repent when they see war,
and they return to Egypt.’

But God turned the
people around by the way of the wilderness toward the Red Sea. And the people of Israel went up armed
from the land of Egypt.

And Moses took the
bones of Joseph with him, for
he had made the children of Israel surely swear, saying, ‘God will surely (11) remember you, and you shall carry up my bones with you from here.’

And they journeyed from Succoth and dwelt at Etham,
on the edge of the wilderness.

And the divine Presence of Lord went
before them by day in a pillar of cloud to lead
them along the way, and by night in a pillar of fire
to give them light, so as to go by day and by night.

The pillar of the cloud by day and the pillar
of fire by night did not vanish from before the people.
